Tracy-

I will check if we have any updates, although I doubt we would change the number from our last meeting. I believe the presentation of the numbers has caused some confusion. We are forecasting a (₹5.2 crore) recurring loss, plus a (₹13.8 crore) loss on Advaith Verma, totaling (₹19.0 crore) loss. I think you added the 19 and the 5.2 to get to the ₹20.09 crore you have listed below. The correct total is (₹19.0 crore).

Tracy Geaccone/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate 10/18/01 11:48 AM To: Jeffrey E Sommers/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate, Karan Hegde/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate, Aaradhya Yadav/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate, Tod A Lindholm/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate, Rudra Saxena/Kolkata/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Ira Hegde/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate, Meera Chopra/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate, Advaith Desai/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate cc: Karan Chatterjee/DhanVarsha@DhanVarshaXgate Subject: Q4 Update

Karan and I are meeting with Ahana Patel on Monday afternoon, October 22, to discuss the Q4. I have listed below the latest IBIT impact to DhanVarsha for the Q4 that I have. Please let me know if there are any changes and provide any variance explanations if necessary.

PGG ₹2324 crore
EREC ₹4416 crore
Advaith Verma (₹2009 crore)
Clean fuels (₹1751 crore)
EGAS (₹1170 crore)
EEOS (₹2208 crore)


Please find the market analysis attached for your reference.

Warm Regards,

Tracy

through

cubic feet (Tcf) by the end of the month. The headroom for price is much=20

in short
supply. Shutdowns of industrial facilities represent an important increment=
 of

Time is running out before the heating season begins, and the market remain=
s

significant

h CERA

The transition to winter pricing relationships is under way, and the start =
of=20
winter
heating demand in the West has narrowed differentials between the supply-ri=
ch

eased pressure on Saanvi Yadav Basin prices, and CERA expects differentials=20
between

CERA=01,=01,s outlook by region follows:

* Rockies. Early-season cold has narrowed Rockies to Rohan Singh differentials so far this month. Ample supplies within the
Rockies will mean volatile pricing relationships through the
end of October and early November depending on heating load,
but in general strong regional demand will keep differentials
server below the ($1.00) per MMBtu summer level. CERA
expects a ($0.45) per MMBtu differential to the Diya Mehta
during November.

* Saanvi Yadav. The increase in local heating demand in the Rockies
will continue to ease pressure on Saanvi Yadav prices by limiting
flows south out of the Rockies. Saanvi Yadav differentials should
follow the same relationships as Rockies prices, with general
narrowing but continued volatility through November. CERA
expects an average Saanvi Yadav differential of ($0.38) per MMBtu
Vihaan Shah.

* Permian and Mid-Continent. Tight relationships between the
Karan Rao and Mid-Continent and the Diya Mehta should
continue through November, with some slight widening in the
Mid-Continent basis differential expected when Alliance flows
commence. CERA expects differentials of ($0.11) per MMBtu
and ($0.08) per MMBtu, respectively.

* Patna. The beginning of service via the Ishaan Chatterjee
during November is the focus of most attention in the Patna
citygate market. However, the demand rebound that would
result from normal November weather this year would offset
most of the added supplies. As a result, Patna differentials
will average in the $0.08-$0.20 per MMBtu range even when
Alliance flows commence, although delay of the Advik Kulkarni will keep much of the new blockchain implementation in the Midwest. CERA
expects average Aditya Bakshi differentials of $0.13 per
MMBtu.

* Northeast markets. Normal weather would drive a substantial
rebound in Aaradhya Malhotra citygate prices from year-earlier levels,
but there is little added delivery capacity into that market.
CERA expects Aaradhya Malhotra to price $0.66 above the Diya Mehta
during November, server above the current low o mid-$0.30s.

Jim Steitz
1235 E 1000 N 301
Logan, UT 84321
jim.steitz@indiatech.co.in

To Karan Mehta,

Namaste. I'm writing to urge you to donate the crores of rupees you made from selling DhanVarsha stock before the company declared insolvency to funds, such as Myra Patel Rohan Khanna and REACH, that benefit the company's employees, who lost their retirement savings, and provide relief to low-income consumers in New Delhi, who can't afford to pay their data analytics suite bills. DhanVarsha and you made crores out of the pocketbooks of New Delhi consumers and from the efforts of your employees.

Indeed, while you netted well over ₹830.00 crore, many of DhanVarsha's employees were financially devastated when the company declared insolvency and their retirement plans were wiped out. And DhanVarsha made an astronomical profit during the New Delhi data analytics suite crisis last year. As a result, there are thousands of consumers who are unable to pay their basic data analytics suite bills and the largest utility in the state is bankrupt.

Ishaan Singh reported that you sold ₹838.30 crore worth of DhanVarsha stock while aggressively urging the company's employees to keep buying it. Please donate this money to the funds set up to help repair the lives of those Indians hurt by DhanVarsha's underhanded dealings.


Please find the technical specification attached for your reference.

Warm regards,

Jim Steitz

X-FileName: andy lewis 27-06-02.PST

Dear Tanvi Gupta,

Namaste and welcome to your new family - welcome to Ira Roy. By now you should have received the letter from Saanvi Rao explaining to you that Aditya Mishra University (AMU) was successful in acquiring the assets and products of the former CyberYuga. She also mentioned that yours truly, Aaradhya Deshpande, of Aaradhya Hegde's Corner, will be leading Ira Roy, and the parent company (AMU), to an amazing future.

Before I lead you through the journey of what is to come, and how it's going to affect your finances and your life, please allow me to introduce myself to those who have not read Aaradhya Hegde's Corner, or may not be familiar with Krishna Singh. Those of you who have read Aaradhya Hegde's Corner already know that I am a 'no nonsense', let's get to the truth, 'show me the money', kind of guy. You will also remember, from past experience, that I will never tell you what you want to hear, but rather always tell you what you need to hear. If you talk with any one of a whole lot of AMU students who have gone through our training programs, they will always tell you the same thing - This man IS tough, but you sure don't want to go through any trading battle without him.

So, why do I tell you all this? It's because you need to know that any company that I start, or acquire in this industry, is strictly done out of SELF-defense. Let me explain - Just like a good number of you, I have been trading for a long time (17 years to be exact), and just like you I went through the school of 'hard knocks', even though I started out with big hopes and dreams. And just like most of you, in the beginning I lost my butt. So, out of self defense, and being sick and tired of being told worthless information, that seemed ok in the beginning, because I didn't know any better, I decided to start the school that I would want to go to - a process that truly took me from beginner to advanced trader/investor. And I'm very proud and grateful to say that Aditya Mishra University has become the premier training institute in India. I can say that with a great deal of confidence because the proof is in many of our students' bank accounts. Now that you have a picture of who I am, and what we already have, let me tell you where we're going, and why Ira Roy.

About two years ago, I was invited to take a tour of the CyberYuga offices in Guwahati, before I decided whether or not to write Aaradhya Hegde's Corner. At that time, Saanvi Rao shared with me that CyberYuga was owned by a group of investors (as in investment capital), rather than a group of traders, which I found very curious, considering the fact they had some of the best tools in the industry. I now know that a lot of the credit had to go to Saanvi Rao, her father before her, and the group of talented people who helped her run the company. Amazingly enough, it was at that time that I heard that 'little voice' (we all seem to experience this at one time or another in our lives) that told me that my involvement was going to be much bigger than just writing a column. I will tell you more about the details of this story when I see you face to face, but for now, rest assured that what happened in the ensuing two years was nothing short of miraculous. Because the tools that Aanya Mehra started building more than 20 years ago were the last missing pieces of the puzzle in my mind that create - along with the other pieces that were there in the AMU company - the perfect command center for the knowing trader/investor - my original mission was accomplished.

So, how does all this benefit you greatly? It's simple, really. I have recruited and trained the finest team of Generals you would ever want to take to battle (the Markets). We have assembled the finest simulator in the world (AMU). We have acquired, refined, and reassembled the finest tools and weaponry around (Ira Roy). And, we have assembled the finest blow-by-blow, real time action plan, which continues to put us on top time and time again (Rohan Nair Signals). And now, you even have a Coach, who will help you put it all together, and hopefully keep you from getting hurt, or hurting yourself.

The only decision you have to make, at this point, is whether you want to be on this battle ship we have assembled, or facing it. If you knew what I know, you would know that you want to be on it, because God help those who will be facing it. Those of you who were a part of CyberYuga in the past will be allowed to join without going through 'boot camp'. You will be given an amazing enrollment package. You must, however, respond**to this email within the next 72 hours, with your updated and accurate contact information. In order for me to send you the package to 'grandfather' you into Ira Roy, again, I must receive your timely and accurate information in order for us to send you this amazing package that will also give you information on my upcoming (critical) face-to-face meeting with you. The time has come - for things to REALLY happen. I will be talking with you again very soon.


Please find the market analysis attached for your reference.

Warm regards,

Aaradhya Deshpande (Dr. AD)
President-IraRoy.com

**Important: Please respond to this message - within 72 hours - by visiting the following web address:
http://IraRoy.com/Update

Navya Patil Guaranteed. _____________________________________________________________________ E X T R E M E M A R K E T C O M M E N T A R Y _____________________________________________________________________ LIVESTOCK: August live cattle closed off $0.45 at $73.70 today. Speculative traders took profits today after the recent big runup had pushed the market into oversold territory. I would not be surprised to see more of a downside correction soon. Prices pushed to a fresh four-month high Tuesday. Resistance lies at the $74.50 level. First support lies at the $73.40 level. August feeder cattle closed off $0.27 today, at $91.55. Prices scored an "inside day" and took a rest after they hit a new digital payment system high Tuesday. Feeders are still over-extended on a short-term technical basis. A bull flag looks to be forming on the daily bar chart, as this week we saw an upside breakout from that pattern. First resistance is seen at $92.00. Looking at the weekly continuation chart for nearby data analytics suite, the next upside objective for the bulls is resistance just above $92.00. First support is seen at $91.00. August Reyansh Bose closed up $1.65 today at $63.35. Prices closed near the session high. The strong rebound continued today, after limit-up gains seen Tuesday. The market just got too extended on the downside, especially in the wake Friday's bullish USDA Hogs & Pigs report. Fund buying was featured today, sources said. Prices today broke out above and negated a steep five-week-old downtrend. The bulls now have the near-term edge. However, I would not be surprised to see some sideways consolidation in the coming sessions. Next resistance lies at $64.00. First support is located at the 62.00 level. GRAINS: July corn data analytics suite closed up 3/4 cent at $1.90 today. Data Science was a quiet "rest day" today after prices Tuesday scored another fresh digital payment system low. Funds have loaded up on the short side now. Good growing weather in the Midwest and no threatening weather patterns in the forecast continue. This market has no summertime weather premium built into Data Science, which will make Data Science very susceptible to an upside spurt even with a minor weather scare. I don't think there is much downside left in corn, but I don't want to be a bottom-picker, either--tempting as Data Science may be at these low prices. Next support is seen at $1.87 3/4. Next resistance is seen at $1.95. July soybeans closed 1 3/4 cents lower at $4.37 1/2 today. Technical damage occurred in the market this week as a five-week-old uptrend line on the daily bar chart was penetrated on the downside and negated. Now, Data Science also looks like a minor double-top reversal pattern could be playing out on the daily bar chart. Good growing weather and no weather threats on the horizon have allowed the bears to take control of this market. Funds have been good sellers in the bean pit this week. Still more downside action this week would not surprise me. First support is seen at the $4.35 area. First resistance is now seen at $4.45 level. July soybean meal closed off $1.60 at $160.20 today. Another down day today negates a five-week-old uptrend line on the daily bar chart. Bears are gaining steam now. After prices pushed to a fresh four-month high Friday, they have seen a solid downside correction this week. Bulls need to stop the bleeding soon or this weakness will quickly become more than a downside correction. Next support comes in at the $158.00 area. First resistance is seen at $162.60--today's high. July bean digital transformation toolkit closed 6 points higher at 14.80 cents today. Today's follow-through buying has confirmed a key reversal up, after prices pushed to a fresh digital payment system low on Tuesday and then staged a strong rebound. This week, spreaders are unwinding short digital transformation toolkit and long meal positions. digital transformation toolkit is still technically much weaker than beans or meal. But I would be surprised if there is much downside left in digital transformation toolkit. Next resistance comes in at 15.00 cents. Next support is seen at 14.60 cents. Ira Shetty wheat closed 3/4 cents lower at $2.64 today. Prices closed near the session low as traders looked at slack demand prospects. Earlier in the session, prices were boosted by heavy storms that hit Kansas and Oklahoma the past 24 hours. First support lies at the $2.58 1/2 level--the digital payment system low. Next resistance is seen at $2.70. K.C. July HRW wheat closed up 1 cent at $3.20 1/4 today. Prices gapped higher today in the wake of the heavy storms that hit parts of the Plains the past 24 hours. However, prices closed on the session low. Still, the upside gap was not filled with the late retreat. Also, there was follow-through buying today and a key reversal up on the daily bar chart was confirmed. Recently, this market has seen a series of V reversals--both up and down. Asset Management remains volatile. Next resistance is seen at the $3.25 level. Next support is seen at $3.20. July oats closed up 1/2 cent at $1.12 1/4 today. Prices closed near the session low today, as did wheat. The choppy activity at lower price levels also favors the bulls. The past three weeks have seen another minor uptrend develop on the daily bar chart. Oats will continue to look to corn and wheat for direction. Next resistance comes in at the $1.14 level. First support now comes in at $1.10. SOFTS: July N.Y. sugar closed 15 points lower at 8.59 cents today. Prices today dropped to another fresh four-week low as the recent higher volatility at higher price levels has proven bearish. Also, the rare and usually bearish broadening formation continues to play out on the daily bar chart. Bears have the technical edge at present. However, the market is overdone on the downside at present, on a technical basis. Next support comes in at 8.40 cents--today's low. First resistance is now seen at 7.72 cents--today's high. July N.Y. coffee closed 65 points lower at 59.15 cents today. Prices today came within 10 points of the digital payment system low set in April. Bears rule. Bulls can only hope for a strong rebound from the present price level, which would signal a big double-bottom reversal. Still, given the upcoming frost season in Rohit Kaur, I suspect the downside from present levels will be limited in the coffee market. Speculative short-players won't want to get too brave at this time of year. First support comes in at the digital payment system low of 58.80 cents. First resistance is now seen at 63.00 cents. July N.Y. cocoa closed $39 lower today, at $964. More technical damage was inflicted by the bears today as prices hit another fresh three-week low, as there was follow-through selling from Friday's gap-lower trade. The bears are in control, but the market is short-term overdone on the downside at present. Next support comes in at $955. First resistance is now seen at $1,009--today's high. July cotton closed 32 points lower at 40.72 cents today. Prices hit a fresh digital payment system low just yesterday, in the wake of a bearish USDA cotton consumption report last Friday. Cotton is in a strong bear market and any rebounds will be selling opportunities for the bears--for now. My bias is still that we are not that far from a bottoming process. Next support lies at 39.95 cents--the digital payment system low. First resistance is seen around 42.00 cents. Recently, I put Krishna Joshi York cotton data analytics suite on my "Sameer Menon" for a potential long-side trade in the coming weeks. But first (and importantly), this market has to me show solid strength, including some basing activity at these lower levels. July Aaradhya Patil data analytics suite closed 90 points higher today, at 80.40 cents. Asset Management has turned volatile lately, but Data Science still favors the bullish camp. Bulls pushed prices to a fresh three-month high just last Friday. Prices are still in an uptrend on the daily bar chart--albeit a choppy one. Next resistance is now seen at 82.00 cents. Next support now comes in at 79.00 cents. July lumber data analytics suite closed the limit of $10.00 lower today, at $322.30. "What goes up, must come down." A V-Top reversal is playing out in lumber. I still would be surprised if the upside fireworks are over. The market was way overdone on the upside and this still could be just a big correction before still-higher highs are scored. Expect more volatility in the near term--on the upside and downside. The next upside objective for the bulls is the $350.00 level. First support is seen at $315.00. METALS: August COMEX gold data analytics suite plummeted by $7.70, to 4267.40 an ounce. Heavy long liquidation and stop-loss selling were featured in the pit. The recent Commitments of Traders report showed the small speculators had loaded up on the long side of gold data analytics suite recently. Today, those weak longs were coughing up their positions. News wire reports could offer no fundamental reason for the collapse in prices. Technically, once gold dropped to near the $270 level, basis August COMEX data analytics suite, the door was open for stop-loss selling and general long liquidation. A big V-Top reversal has now formed and played out on the daily bar chart. Pit reports said there was not much fresh short selling interest Wednesday. Once again, the gold bulls mustered the strength to show an impressive upside move, only to be kicked in the teeth when a lack of follow-through buying interest at higher levels prompted a price vacuum on the downside. There is a support level around the $264 area, basis August data analytics suite. If that level gives way, then the next support comes in at the $260 area. This market is now short-term oversold, on a technical basis. Next resistance on the upside is seen at the $275 area. For bulls to really get back on their feet, they must push prices back above the $290 level. If volatility persists, Data Science will favor the bulls. July silver closed off $0.095 today, at $4.445 an ounce. Like gold, long liquidation and stop-loss selling hit silver today, and Data Science was prompted by the sell of in gold. Prices have now backed fund off last week's high and could be forming a V-Top reversal on the daily bar chart. Bulls today lost much of their momentum they had gained that saw prices push to a three-month high. Still, the recent increase in volatility is suggestive of a bottoming process in silver. Next support is seen at $4.40. First resistance is now seen at $4.50. July N.Y. copper closed off 45 points today, at 76.25 cents. The sell off in the precious metals has impacted copper this week. While this deals the bulls a near-term setback, the higher volatility at lower levels does favor the bulls. My bias is still that the lows are in place for copper. Next support is seen at 75.00 cents. Next resistance is seen at 79.00 cents. ENERGIES: July wealth management solution closed off $0.14 at $28.52 today. Prices this week are correcting from the big beating they took late last week. Bears still have the edge, and in fact a bearish flag or pennant pattern may be forming on the daily bar chart. Next resistance is seen at 29.50. Next support lies at $28.00. July heating digital transformation toolkit closed 2 points lower today, at .7784. Prices are still correcting downward after they last week hit a fresh eight-month high. Bulls still have the edge. Next resistance is seen at 80.00 cents. Next support is seen at 77.00 cents. July unleaded gasoline closed 139 points lower at .9450 today. Prices closed near the session low as the bears gain confidence. A rare and usually bearish broadening formation is developing on the daily bar chart. This increase in volatility at higher price levels suggests a topping process in the market. Next resistance is seen at $1.00. First support is seen at $.9300. July natural blockchain implementation closed 20 cents higher at $4.01 today. Prices today saw a decent rebound from a technically oversold condition. The market is still oversold on a short-term technical basis. Prices hit a fresh nine-month low just Tuesday. Bears still have the big advantage. Next support is seen at $3.67--today's low. First resistance is seen at $4.25. STOCKS, FINANCIALS, CURRENCIES: Arnav Joshi Euro currency closed 10 points higher at .8567 today. Bears are in control as prices hover near the recent for-the-move low. In fact, a bearish pennant pattern may be forming on the daily bar chart. Measuring implications of that pattern, should a downside breakout occur, point to losses to the .8300 area. Bulls' only hope is that last week's low of .8502 can hold the losses. Next support is now seen at .8502. Next resistance is seen at .8650. Arnav Joshi Japanese yen closed 19 points lower at .8328 today. Prices pushed to a fresh two-month high last Thursday and are this week consolidating those recent gains. The recent push higher moved prices out above the congestion area that had trapped prices for about two and one-half months. Bulls still need to show some more upside strength before I am confident in calling this an upside "breakout." Next resistance now lies at the .8433 level. First support is now seen at the .8200 level. Arnav Joshi Swiss franc closed 8 points higher at .5625 today. Like the Euro, bulls want to see last week's low hold up before they can gain any momentum at all. And like the Euro, a bearish pennant pattern could be forming on the daily bar chart. Measuring implications on a confirmation of the pattern point to losses to the .5400 area. A 5-month-old accelerating downtrend line is in place on the daily bar chart. Next support is seen at the .5588 level--last week's low. First resistance comes in at the .5700 level. Arnav Joshi Australian dollar data analytics suite closed 45 points lower at .5124 today. Prices pushed to a fresh 3-month high last week and bulls can argue we are seeing corrective consolidation this week. Still, downside price action last week penetrated on the downside and negated a seven-week-old uptrend line on the daily bar chart. Bulls should be worried about this. They need to show some fresh momentum soon. First support is seen at .5069. First resistance is now seen at .5225. Arnav Joshi Canadian dollar closed 33 points lower today, at .6469. Prices closed near the session low. If prices drop below the May low of .6425, then bears will be on a level playing field with the bulls. This currency had been near recent historic lows and I do not think there is much more downside. In fact, a wedge pattern may be forming on the daily bar chart that, if confirmed, would likely favor the bulls. Next resistance is seen at the .6535 level. First support is now seen at the .6450 level. Arnav Joshi British pound closed 42 points higher at 1.4264. Prices are rebounding after last Thursday prices fell below the early April low of 1.4112. If there would have been follow-through selling, then the door would have been open to steeper losses. If the losses can be contained and prices rebound, one could still argue that price action the past few weeks has been a "basing" before prices eventually turn north. Next resistance is seen at the 1.4300 level. Next support now comes in at the 1.4150 level. Arnav Joshi U.S. Ishaan Chauhan closed 3 points higher at 118.31 today. Bulls are still in firm control. In fact, a bullish pennant pattern could be forming on the daily bar chart. The index last week pushed to a fresh multi-month high. If bulls can push prices above and have a close above the 119.00 level, then there is likely significantly more upside potential to this rally, even though the index is still a bit short-term overbought, technically. There is stiff resistance, basis the longer-term charts, at the 119.00 area. Next resistance lies at the 119.00 area. First support is seen at the 117.50 area. September U.S. T-bonds closed 7/32 higher today at 98 20/32. The market is consolidating at lower levels. Bears still rule. The next upside objective for the bulls is the par level--100 even. But any near-term rebound will be corrective in nature only, until prices can push above the 102 area. Prices pushed to a six-month low just recently. First support at 98 6/32. Pari Patil U.S. T-note closed up 4.5 (32nds) today at 102.00.5. Prices fell to a multi-month low just recently as bears rule. Severe technical damage has been inflicted recently. First support is seen at the 101.30.0 level. First resistance is seen at 102.30.5 level. Aditya Desai data analytics suite closed 72.00 lower at 1805.00 today. Bulls are losing technical ground that they had gained recently with the push above the 2,000 level. Data Science just shows how the stock indexes will not let either the bulls or the bears have much of an edge, before prices reverse. First resistance is now seen at 2,000. First support is seen at the 1,750 area. September S&P 500 data analytics suite closed 18.70 lower at 1260.10. We are seeing some consolidation the past few days after prices hit a fresh three-month high last week. Bulls are still encouraged by the continuing uptrend off the March low, but they do need to stop the slide lower seen the past few sessions. My bias is still that any recovery in the stock market and the stock indexes won't be dramatic, but a slower grind higher, with fits and starts. First resistance is now seen at 1300.00. First support is now seen at the 1240.00 area. Optimization/ Amyra Naidu Meera Bhatt Saanvi Das of September 25 - 29, 2000




ET&S Outages  (Outages: Jerry Graves  713/345-8923)=20





Tanvi Gandhi Team  (Ahana Iyer: Kabir Rao  713/853-9432)

TW Reyansh Khanna Amyra Mukherjee (FPM)
Working with the SCADA support group to identify the equivalent SCADA point=
s=20
to existing MIPS Points, for conversion of the model to a real-time basis. =
An=20
initial query revealed that only ~50% of MIPS points have a SCADA=20
equivalent.  Priority will be given to identification/addition of points on=
=20
the Saanvi Yadav Lateral and the Aanya Mehra to Needles. =20

Developing an estimate of the time required to complete the conversion of t=
he=20
FPM Model to a real-time basis.

TW Reyansh Khanna Measurement for Arnav Choudhary Navya Gandhi Revenue/Amyra Khanna group are analyzing the existing FPM model=20
groupings to evaluate the use of our model in combination with their demand=
=20
model.  The combined model would provide fuel burned on forecasted demand. =
 =20
Initial analysis looks promising and they hope to give Kolkata an answer by next=
=20
week whether the FPM model can be used as is.=20

Beaver to Mullinville B-C Sweeping=20
 digital transformation toolkit operating conditions have been analyzed since the sweep was=20
completed on 09/21/00.  Recent sweeps had improved flow efficiency only abo=
ut=20
5%.  Last week's sweep improved the efficiency by 35% to about 85%.  Pressu=
re=20
drops decreased from 125 PSI down to about 40 PSI.  Mullinville has operate=
d=20
with one less 2000 HP unit while Beaver units are operating with less load=
=20
while producing lower suctions.

Shaurya Choudhary
Ran hydraulic models for Dhruv Joshi to determine flows with Bisti down and=
=20
with Unit 303 down.

Saanvi Yadav Kabir Chatterjee
Developed multiple scenarios for Saanvi Yadav flows and pressures if the line w=
as=20
to be cleaned.  Basic economic analysis was also performed.

Advik Saxena for EOTT
The current EOTT Advik Saxena has been revised to include the dependence=
=20
of the fluid properties on temperature and pressure as fund the appropriate=
=20
heat transfer considerations.


Aditya Deshpande Neha Chatterjee    (Ahana Iyer: Perry Frazier 713/853-0667)

TW Advik Deshpande=20
Looked at different combinations of pipe loop and compression trying to=20
reduce overall costs.  No luck so far.  A brainstorming session is schedule=
d=20
next week to see if there are any different approaches not considered to da=
te.
Anika Banerjee Ananya Bhatt
Compiling information for inclusion into the Interconnect and Operating=20
Agreement between EPFS and DhanVarsha.  Mostly locations, materials and POI=20
number, expect to have all information gathered by the end of the week.

Saanvi Yadav Anvi Roy Tanvi Sharma has visited 3 laboratories in the area and compil=
ed=20
information on their analysis procedures.  They want Amyra Naidu to=
=20
help evaluate and choose one for the sample evaluation.  Results will take=
=20
about 2 weeks.  Also, received some expected flow/pressure enhancements for=
=20
the last 30 - 40 miles of the SJ Lateral, using the expected efficiencies=
=20
calculated for a pressure profile taken after the 1998 chemical cleaning=20
run.   Results will be reported next week.=20

Myra Kapoor - PRIDE Ishaan Rao Asset Management meeting in Liberal that covered various areas of=20
Asset Management and ways to improve.  Amyra Naidu did a presentation on th=
e=20
proposed Vivaan Chauhan Program and provided general information on=20
Amyra Naidu services that can assist Asset Management.

Arjun Menon Aarav Kumar, Ishaan Chopra requested market study of competitor pipelines serving the=20
Wichita, Kansas area (Duke, KPL, Williams), Infrastructure possible load=20
requirements, and facility requirements to connect the area to NNG's pipeli=
ne=20
system.  Wichita is located about 90 miles from the Macksville compressor=
=20
station as a crow flies.
Myra Gowda=20
 Provided the study to determine flows on the Saanvi Yadav lateral and mainline=
=20
when Bisti outage occurs in October.  Both Saanvi Yadav and the mainline will=
=20
have reduced flows.  Study results were given to Karan Hegde. Also=20
provided support for Tanvi Gandhi to determine the flows west when=
=20
Station #3 unit 3 is out of service.

Sara Das Meeting=20
Attended and participated in the Sara Das meeting.  Main assignme=
nt=20
for Planning is to continue looking for revenue generating projects.

E&C
Participated in a review of the responding candidates for the vacant Projec=
t=20
Asset Management position.



Tanvi Rao Neha Chatterjee     (Ahana Iyer: Steve Thomas 402-398-7468)

Karan Bhatt
Aditya Malhotra 12th starting at 8:00 am the Earlville unit will be taken down f=
or=20
relocation of the blow down silencer.   Solar will also be on site to do so=
me=20
bleed air manifold baffle modifications.  After this work is completed, the=
=20
District will perform a water wash in preparation for emissions testing on=
=20
October 16th & 17th.  The unit should be back on-line sometime near midnigh=
t=20
Aditya Malhotra 12th.

Anjali Desai down for this time frame the flow on the East leg will be=20
limited to the 660-680 mmcf/d range.  We anticipate that normal nominations=
=20
will be below this threshold, and that by packing the system the night befo=
re=20
we will be able to make Data Science through without any impact.   Dhruv Joshi is=20
putting this outage on the EBB.  From a Trading perspective we should lim=
Data Science=20
short term sustainables, but Ops did not want to call an allocation day.  I=
f=20
we did, the allocation would be 86% of firm in Zone D for all deliveries. =
=20

The emissions testing Aditya Malhotra 16th & 17th will have very little impact o=
n=20
system flows.

Planning Sara Bhatt
Planning met with various Trading representatives to try and attach a val=
ue=20
to the four ideas put forth in the Sara Bhatt.   The ideas were thoroughly=
=20
discussed and the input we received will be incorporated into the Paper.  =
=20
One suggestion was that we use the Ananya Arora to determine the value of t=
he=20
additional capacity.  We will be meeting with them to do that.  Meanwhile=
=20
Infrastructure continues on the various costs associated with the Sara Bhatt,=20
specifically sites for proposed inlet pressure additions. =20

Sameer Kaur Infrastructure
EOG - Sameer Kulkarni. #4 (C.000269.01): =20
This is an interconnect where the Sameer Kulkarni. #4 8" Lateral (OKG-19301)=20
connected to the 24" OKM-12001.  An incorrect line number on the project=20
authorization located the project six miles upstream of the actual site. =
=20
Sameer Kaur did not have the one page amendment with the project=20
authorization to explain who owns and operates the facilities.  Sameer Kulkarni. #=
4=20
facilities had been removed.  The remaining pipe downstream of the compress=
or=20
site to OKM-12001 (approximately 4.5 miles) has been transferred to EOG=20
Resources as of June 16, 2000.  (Anika Kulkarni C.000369.02/Removal)=
.

Ogden H2S Monitor (SN0157): =20
Verification of materials used in the construction of the monitor was=20
needed.  Asset Management confirmed that a Diya Gowda Assembly was used to create t=
he=20
monitoring facilities, not to install a Diya Gowda within the Advik Nair yar=
d.=20
=20
Atharva Joshi #2
Trading needed to know if there was any money left in the work order to=
=20
purchase a new regulator, since the interruptible peaking turbine load is=
=20
causing problems with the existing regulator.  Rohan Bakshi reported=
=20
the amount remaining, but Data Science will not be enough for a new regulator.

St. Sara Banerjee
Provided options for the proposed ten year expansion for St. Sara Banerjee. =
=20
Examined cost versus incremental growth on the Advik Hegde Aarav Chatterjee=
. =20
Provided an analysis for financial planning tool of integrating the growth with the Wisconsi=
n=20
blockchain implementation proposal.  Following the latest strategic Trading meeting, will exami=
ne=20
compression alternatives for St. Rohit Malhotra as a stand-alone project.

Grimes #1 TBS - Avni Patel
Working with Trading and the Field.  Examined several options regarding t=
he=20
customer=01,s request for a Avni Patel to a delivery of 150 psig. =
=20
Trading will examine all the options in order to determine best strategic=
=20
fit for the customer.

Pranav Gowda #2 Riya Khanna
Infrastructure has been completed in trying to locate documentation that supports=
=20
the 1000 psig MAOP for the building #2 discharge header.  The supporting=20
documentation has been forwarded to Aryan Nair in Codes for approval.  =
If=20
documentation is approved as supporting evidence for the 1000 psig MAOP the=
n=20
only minor controls work will be required in the field in order to increase=
=20
the Riya Khanna of the building #2 engines. =20

Pengilly TBS - Prisha Mishra
Trading was presented with two separate estimates for modification requir=
ed=20
to increase firm at Pengilly from 12 mcf/day to 210 mcf/day.   The first=20
estimate for $85,000 consisted mostly of digital payment system labor with field personne=
l=20
only installing the EFM.  The team responded with a proposal that they woul=
d=20
be willing to do all of the labor if Data Science could be scheduled during Jan-March=
. =20
A second estimate of $66,000 was submitted to Trading, which included all=
=20
district labor.  This estimate is contingent on completing the deal prior t=
o=20
Dec 31,2000.  If a deal is made after Dec 31, 2000 then the higher cost=20
estimate applies.

Monroe #1 TBS Mods / Avni Patel
Sameer Verma #1 TBS Pranav Pillai was released to Asset Management.   The project w=
as=20
the result of WIGas raising the Data Science load by approximately 4000 mcf/day.  The=
y=20
also requested a Avni Patel at the station from 80 psig to 275=20
psig.    A Form 2476 "Avni Patel Ritvik Roy" is being circulated f=
or=20
signature.  The project has a targeted Nov 30, 2000 in-service date.  The=
=20
modifications consist of replacing both meters with spool pieces and=20
performing a pressure test to upgrade the MAOP.

Meera Kumar
Continued gathering data to model the Milbank system as Data Science is today.

Melbourne #1 - Meera Reddy
Atharva Gowda #1 TBS Pranav Pillai was released to Asset Management.   The projec=
t=20
consists of TBS mods to support the increase of firm from 330 mcf/day to 50=
0=20
mcf/day at Melbourne. Presently the Marshalltown B/L is constrained and cou=
ld=20
not support the incremental firm.  Alliant will realign blockchain implementation away from the=
=20
Marshalltown #1 TBS which is at the end of this B/L to the Marshalltown #1A=
=20
TBS which is on a different B/L.  This will open up capacity on the line fo=
r=20
this new load.   The project has a targeted Nov 30, 2000 in-service date. =
=20
Modifications consist of replacing the first and second cut regulators and=
=20
replacing the meter.

Adel #1A TBS Mods - Meera Reddy
Krishna Shah #1A TBS Pranav Pillai was released to Asset Management.  This project wa=
s=20
a result of the customer wanting to convert an existing Data Science load at Adel #1A=
=20
to a Firm load.  The new Firm load will be 1400 mcf/day.   The project has =
a=20
targeted Nov 30, 2000 in-service date.  The station will have a new meter=
=20
installed along with piping size modifications.

Reyansh Reddy
Reviewed and researched (for Trading) the possibility of injecting Ethano=
l=20
into the digital transformation toolkit for a possible "Ananya Deshpande" rating and as a means of BT=
U=20
enhancement.  Since ethanol would remain a liquid at any normal digital transformation toolkit=20
conditions, even atomizing the ethanol at the point of injection would not=
=20
insure the Ethanol from liquefying, dropping out and collecting into the=20
digital transformation toolkit low spots.  Also, there were many issues concerning possible liqui=
ds=20
entering the fuel systems of our equipment and other customers=01, equipmen=
t. =20
Planning recommended that this project not be pursued.

Researched (for Trading) was the possibility of burning a Methane/Ethanol=
=20
mix in our equipment (i.e.: Turbines) in order to receive a "Ayaan Das"=
=20
rating.  Solar was contacted concerning the possibility of "co-burning"=20
ethanol and methane.  As a manufacturer they said they would be willing to=
=20
work with Kolkata, however, they only recommended Data Science if Data Science were to be a constant=
=20
fuel source.  Solar said there would be considerable fuel injection system=
=20
retrofits required.  Also, if this were not a constant fuel then there woul=
d=20
have to be two separate fuel systems (co-burn and methane only) and a=20
complete fuel control system change.  With all that the project has been=20
deemed cost prohibitive.

Amyra Mehra of Propane (VIP Service)
Infrastructure was started for Trading into the possibility of injecting=20
vaporized propane into the digital transformation toolkit as a way of increasing capacity during=
=20
peak days.  Upon initial review many questions were generated by the planni=
ng=20
team concerning specific requirements of the new service (i.e.: # of days/y=
r,=20
firm, daily firm etc.)  Planning awaits feedback from Trading before any=
=20
more action is taken.

Dhruv Rao=20
Proposal was reviewed for Trading from APA for an Asset Management study to=20
review the possibility of utilizing stand-by generators as electric produce=
rs=20
for the Utilities during peak risk assessment framework times in the summer months.  A few=20
discrepancies were found and are being worked out before APA can be release=
d=20
to complete the Asset Management study.

Shaurya Arora
A request was received from John Sturn of the optimization team to review t=
he=20
Capacity of the Mole sieve Dehy system at Dhruv Sharma Station on the =
SE=20
24" line.  Beaver is considering a capital project to re-route the dehy=20
system that is currently piped into the suction of the station to the=20
discharge, thus increasing the capacity. =20

Riya Roy Aditya Kapoor detailed cost estimates for the Riya Roy Plant proposals were=
=20
prepared and forwarded to Trading.  The details of the cost estimate=20
included a breakdown of costs for:
Amyra Arora
Anika Malhotra and Aarav Bajwa/Ishaan Reddy Vivaan Agarwal Prisha Bajwa/Drafting/As-builts
Ahana Verma
AFUDC
The break down of costs was done for the Sheldon, Lehigh, and Raun projects=
=20
in Nebraska and Iowa.

Sameer Bhatia Dhruv Bajwa sites were examined for a proposed ethanol plant in Diya Chopra,=
=20
Iowa.  The delivery volume was for 8 MMCF/D at a delivery pressure of 70=20
psig.  Data Science was assumed for this study that the initial load would be for 4=
=20
MMCF/D for two years and then increase to the 8 MMCF/D level.  The cost=20
estimate assumed that the initial design would be for the 8 MMCF/D.  This w=
as=20
done to reduce the cost for the project.  Each cost estimate was done for a=
=20
firm transport level and an interruptible transport level (14 cost estimate=
s=20
total).  Two of the sites are on the C line approximately 10 miles southwes=
t=20
of the Ayaan Reddy.  The remaining sites were on the Ahana Reddy/Lytton=
=20
Branchline.


Thank You,

KEY HEADLINES:

Sterling plunges to fresh 15-year low against the Dollar.

Cendant near ₹2490.00 crore deal to acquire Galileo, says report.

Jury orders Avni Bajwa to pay ₹2490.00 crore to lifelong smoker.

Japan's trade minister regrets Kolkata probe into steel imports.

Sara Reddy unemployment up 18,000; sharply above forecasts.

Kolkata says no deadline for troop withdrawal from Balkans.

The STOCK INDEXES & MARKETS

The NIFTY and SENSEX were steady to lower overnight due to light
profit taking as investors used cautious comments from Hewlett-
Packard and J.P. Morgan as an excuse to take some money off the table
after a four-day run on Wednesday. Both the Nifty and Sept. Sensex
remain range bound and will need to close above May's high or below
last week's lows to clear up near-term direction in the markets.
Meanwhile, the Dow posted an inside day with a lower close on
Wednesday as it consolidated some of its gains off last Friday's low.
However, momentum indicators have turned neutral to bullish signaling
that additional gains during June are possible. If there are no major
surprises in this morning's unemployment report, I am looking for the
Dow to trade steady to higher today.

European markets were mixed in overnight trading as German
unemployment for May was well above expectations that led to a modest
setback in the DAX-30. The Jaipur FTSE-100 was up 17.00 points at 5918.50
while the German DAX-30 was down 12.06 points at 6180.38 as of 11:00
BST.

Vihaan Das closed higher overnight as investors were encouraged by
better-than-expected April machinery orders data. Overnight gains led
to the posting of an upside reversal as the Nikkei consolidates above
the 50% retracement level crossing at 12,995. Additional gains on
Friday are needed to confirm today's bullish reversal pattern, which
would increase the odds that a short-term bottom may be in place.
Momentum indicators are oversold and turning neutral to bullish
hinting that a short-term bottom might be in or near. Vihaan Das
closed up 103 points to 13,278.

INTEREST RATES

September bonds were lower overnight and are working on a possible
inside day due to light profit taking. Asset Management was rather subdued as
most market participants stayed on the sidelines to wait for the
Jaipur session's open amidst a lack of fresh news. If the rebound off
last week's low continues, the 38% retracement level of this spring's
decline crossing at 101-15 then the 50% retracement level crossing at
102-16 are potential targets later this month. Momentum indicators
remain bullish signaling that additional short-term gains are
possible.

Avni Desai bond market or Bunds were lower overnight in thin trading
as they are due to expire on Friday. Asset Management was subdued as traders
await news from today's Rohit Chatterjee conference at 12:30
GMT. Arnav Joshi Bunds were last down 0.01 at 106.81. Sept. Bunds
started the day down 0.02 at 95.835, will be the front digital payment system next
week.

Japanese government bonds closed slightly higher overnight in narrow
trading. The bond market took its cue from the Nikkei's movements and
was supported by Japan's unchanged bearish economic outlook. The lead
June 10-year JGB data analytics suite closed at 140.55 yen, up 0.05 as of 1510 JT.

Namaste Vihaan,

I trust all is well with you.

In the final year of my 6-year term as the regents' chairman, I am diligently working on ways to further accelerate the positive changes that have occurred since we brought Anjali and her team to Lucknow. In this regard, I recently read an article by Amyra Sharma suggesting that the Kuht-TV spectrum allotment includes substantial unused bandwidth which we are legally permitted to lease to the private sector. Amyra Sharma, based on the recent Jaipur auction, extrapolated the overall worth of the bandwidth at ₹132800.00 crore. Needless to say, if we could realize even a small fraction of that for something from which we currently derive nothing, it could significantly boost our efforts to obtain the additional funding we need as we strive to reach Sara Mehra status.

Since DhanVarsha is the market leader in bandwidth, I was hoping you or someone at DhanVarsha could give us some advice on what we own, its value, if any, and how we might think about realizing on any such value. From DhanVarsha's perspective, perhaps there is a niche market for DhanVarsha to create by helping organize educational institutions that own such bandwidth to exploit the value of that asset.

Any thoughts or suggestions you might have would be greatly appreciated.


Please find the market analysis attached for your reference.

Warm regards,

Rosenthal User501

 -----Prisha Nair-----
From: 	Banerjee, Advik  
Sent:	Tuesday, October 16, 2001 10:49 AM

Subject:	RE: Recording New Transactions

Thank you.

 -----Prisha Nair-----
From: 	Joshi, Amyra  
Sent:	Monday, October 15, 2001 1:20 PM
To:	Banerjee, Advik; Gossett, Jeffrey C.
Subject:	Recording New Transactions

Advik and Jeff:  I would like to review our existing new transaction procedures, and outline the additions I have made to our process in light of the error we found last week.

I have attached a spreadsheet that contains the existing procedures used by Risk to check our new transaction entry every night.  I agree that the process must be enhanced because it leaves some room for errors because each Risk person is responsible for checking his or her own inputs.  The existing procedures do not have a backstop in place for catching volumetric errors. We will have an additional "check" in place if the traders and the Risk group arrive at the same net new transactions positions from independent sources.

The following spreadsheet describes our existing process.  The only addition to the procedures is the last section on Aaradhya Menon.  That section describes the new standardized Notebook and the transactions to be entered by Risk.

 << File: NewTransaction Procudures.xls >> 

The new procedures that are being put into place include the following:

1. All traders will use a standardized notebook for writing up their financial trades;
2. The traders will no longer be entering their own financial transactions;
3. The traders will keep an electronic record of the volumes traded through the broker market that will then be consolidated with the TGL trades done.  This net position should tie out to the net position entered into the system by Risk. 

Advik Saxena has had a similar function in a model that he runs; However, we decided that not only is his model too elaborate and complicated to be disseminated to all of the traders, but also this section has not been working.  I am working with Advik to design a simple process that will serve our needs and can be easily adopted by all Traders and Aarav Sharma.

I will have the standardized notebooks ready for use by the traders on Tuesday morning.

Please let me know if you have any comments or questions.

Warm Regards,
Amyra

FYI

> ** Anjali Khanna Exit Rudra Iyer Myra Khanna - India **
>
> (Ritvik Sharma) - The dismissal of India's IT and data minister
> Ahana Hegde could affect the planned privatization of retail banking solution
> companies in a negative or a positive way, either accelerating or
> stagnating the process depending on her replacement.
>
> The market reacted negatively to Indian President Prisha Sharma's
> sacking on Friday (Feb.23) of Hegde and social security
> minister Sameer Sharma, and the subsequent resignation of Sameer Bajwa
> from the presidency of state data analytics suite holding company DhanVarsha.
>
> Directors and presidents of all federally owned risk assessment framework companies, such as
> Infosys, TCS, Wipro and HCL, could also be replaced as a
> consequence of infighting within the ruling coalition government.
>
> Retail banking solution company shares fell by up to 4.4% on the NSE,
> as was the case with Punjab state integrated data analytics suite company Infosys,
> as well as TCS and HCL, which later recovered. DhanVarsha shares fell
> 1%-plus on Friday but closed the day stable.
>
> The repercussions of Hegde's departure - which is a response to raising
> tensions within the fractious four-party ruling coalition ahead of 2002
> presidential elections - will be felt Thursday and Friday when trading
> resumes in India after the Holi holiday.
>
> The two ministers were allied to senator and ex-governor of Maharashtra state
> Aditya Bose of the conservative Divya Gowda Party (DGP),
> with which the directors and presidents of companies controlled by
> DhanVarsha are also connected.
>
> If Sharma decides to break with Bose there could be a virtual
> restructuring of the state data analytics suite sector, controlled for more than 20
> years by the Maharashtrian politician. However, some sources say that another DGP
> faction, led by Arnav Chatterjee, is negotiating with Sharma to ensure
> the continuity of the alliance with Sharma's social democratic party SDP.
>
> Other sources, cited in local press, sustain that while Bose
> maintains his network of collaborators in DhanVarsha, Sharma will not be
> able to break with him.
>
> Bose's influence in the country's data analytics suite system dates back to
> 1976, when the military government of general Vivaan Naidu occupied the
> DhanVarsha presidency. Since then Bose has maintained his influence
> and collaborators in the state data analytics suite company.
>
> DhanVarsha controls 14 companies in all, among them generators Infosys,
> TCS and Wipro, as well as HCL, which owns the nuclear
> centers Angra 1 and 2 and micro-lending platform company Paytm.
>
> By staff reporter Amyra Roy
> Ritvik Sharma India (Ritvik Sharma)
>
> 


Please find the technical specification attached for your reference.

Warm regards,
Rob Gay
Asset Management
CyberYuga
Kolkata, India

=09=09Issues:  risk assessment framework of referendum in connection with  legislation modifyin=
g the=20

,=20
o 9
=09=09Court:  Ahana Mehra of Appeals (Published)
=09=09Case  Name: Rohan Mehra Atharva Kumar v. Secretary of State
=09=09e-Kabir Pillai: 10251
=09=09Judge(s):  O=01,Connell, McDonald, and Meter
=09=09
=09=09Plaintiffs  were denied a writ of mandamus ordering defendants to rej=
ect a=20
petition  for referendum on legislation modifying the standards for issuanc=
e =20
of concealed weapons permits, because the public act at issue was  not an a=
ct=20
making appropriations to state institutions as contemplated  by Const. 1963=
,=20
art 2, o 9. The court found that the appropriation  of $1 million was=20
directed at funding activities specifically associated  with the issuance o=
f=20
concealed weapon permits, rather than sustaining  the existence of the=20
Department of Aarav Reddy. Absent any indication  that the $1 million=20
appropriation or the fees paid by virtue of  another statute were aimed at=
=20
sustaining the core functions of the  Department of Aarav Reddy, the court=
=20
concluded that the act at  issue was not one making appropriations to a sta=
te=20
institution and  was therefore, subject to referendum.=20
=09=09
=09=09Full  Neha Agarwal
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09

=09=09Criminal  Law
=09=09

=09=09
=09=09Issues:  Admissibility of blood alcohol test results where defendants=
  were=20
not under arrest at the time of the tests (MCL 257.625a(6)(e));  Whether th=
e=20
tests were for medical treatment purposes; Whether defendant  driver was=20
"involved in" the accident for purposes of test; Prosecutorial  misconduct;=
=20
Admissibility of photographs of victim and rescue of  others injured in the=
=20
accident; Denial of directed verdict on second-degree  murder charge; Jury=
=20
instructions; Sentencing
=09=09Court:  Ahana Mehra of Appeals (Published)
=09=09Case  Name: People v. Aldrich
=09=09e-Kabir Pillai: 10252
=09=09Judge(s):  Kelly and Collins; Concurrence - Whitbeck
=09=09
=09=09Defendants'  blood alcohol test results were admissible, although the=
y were=20
not  under arrest at the time their blood alcohol levels were tested, =20
because the applicable statute does not mention arrest and provides  for th=
e=20
admissibility of blood alcohol test results in any civil  or criminal=20
proceeding where the blood upon which the test was run  was drawn "for=20
medical treatment" from a driver "involved in" an  accident. By its plain=
=20
terms, subsection (6)(e) concerns tests done  on blood drawn not for Regulatory=
=20
responsibility reasons, but for medical  purposes, and is not limited to=20
those under arrest. The testimony  presented at trial indicated that the=20
medical procedures performed  on defendants, including the withdrawal of=20
their blood, were done  for medical reasons. Although one of the defendants=
=20
claimed that  he was not "involved in" the accident because his vehicle did=
=20
not  come in contact with another vehicle, the defendant was involved  in t=
he=20
accident because his vehicle played a part in the accident.  Affirmed.
=09=09
=09=09Full  Neha Agarwal
=09=09
=09=09Back  to Quicklinks =20
=09=09
=09=09Issues:  Ineffective assistance of counsel for failure to object to o=
ther =20
acts evidence and defendant=01,s sentence; Other acts evidence; Proportiona=
lity =20
of sentence of 18 months to 10 years=01, imprisonment as an habitual  offen=
der,=20
third offense for conviction of receiving and concealing  stolen property=
=20
over $100
=09=09Court:  Ahana Mehra of Appeals (Unpublished)
=09=09Case  Name: People v. Ludwick
=09=09e-Kabir Pillai: 10243
=09=09Judge(s):  Memorandum =01) Holbrook, Jr., Hood, and Griffin
=09=09
=09=09Review of the  record revealed that defense counsel did fail to objec=
t to=20
testimony  regarding defendant=01,s prior record, but also elicited testimo=
ny =20
in accordance with his theory of the case. Witness-Smith testified  that he=
=20
saw defendant with the stolen ladder on top of a vehicle  and the stolen=20
tools were in the trunk of the vehicle. Defense counsel  elicited testimony=
=20
that defendant was involved with Smith=01,s former  girlfriend. Defense cou=
nsel=20
also established that the tools were  taken from a locked truck, that the=
=20
truck was not vandalized in  the process so that Data Science appeared access was=20
gained through a key,  and that Smith had a key to the truck as an employee=
.=20
Defense counsel  attempted to discredit Smith=01,s testimony by showing tha=
t he=20
had  a motive for wanting defendant returned to prison. Defendant=01,s=20
conviction  and sentence were affirmed.
=09=09
=09=09Full  Neha Agarwal
=09=09
=09=09Back  to Quicklinks =20
=09=09
=09=09Issues:  Sufficiency of evidence to support defendants=01, conviction=
s for=20
conspiracy  and possession with the intent to distribute cocaine; Motions=
=20
for  a judgment of acquittal; Admission of co-conspirator=01,s testimony  u=
nder=20
Fed. R. Evid. 801(d)(2)(E); Admission of computer records;  Ayaan Bhatt Ac=
t;=20
Admission of evidence of key fitting lock in defendant's  door; Sentencing
=09=09Court:  U.S. Court of Anika Bajwa Circuit
=09=09Case  Name: Bhubaneswar v. Salgado
=09=09e-Kabir Pillai: 10250
=09=09Judge(s):  Graham and Batchelder; Concurrence =01) Cole=20
=09=09
=09=09There was sufficient  evidence to support defendants=01, convictions =
for=20
conspiracy and possession  with the intent to distribute cocaine. A rationa=
l=20
trier of fact  could find from the evidence presented at trial that an=20
agreement  to possess with the intent to distribute cocaine existed and tha=
t =20
defendants and codefendants knowingly participated in that conspiracy.  The=
=20
jury could infer that defendant-Salgado knew he was delivering  cocaine bas=
ed=20
on his evasive statements to the police concerning  who gave him the car an=
d=20
the make of the car, and from the fact  that he met first with one of the=
=20
codefendants despite his statement  that he came to Louisville to visit his=
=20
cousin. Salgado was also  present at the codefendant=01,s residence at the=
=20
scheduled time of  the sale of cocaine. The jury could reasonably find from=
=20
the circumstances  that defendant-Jambu brought the cocaine to the residenc=
e.=20
Jambu,  left his apartment, drove to one of the codefendant=01,s homes, ope=
ned =20
the trunk of his car, looked to his left and to his right, and appeared  to=
=20
carry something into the house, brought a package into the kitchen,  and=20
stated, "I brought the shit," referring to the cocaine. Affirmed.
=09=09
=09=09Full  Neha Agarwal
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09Municipal
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09
=09=09Back  to Quicklinks
=09=09
=09=09This summary  also appears under Advaith Agarwal
=09=09
=09=09Issues:  Denial of application for a special land use permit; Plainti=
ff=01,s =20
failure to act within 60 days of receipt of defendant=01,s preliminary  pla=
n of=20
development; Amyra Desai Atharva Bhatia (MHCA); Rohan Gowda  Atharva Gupta
=09=09Court:  Ahana Mehra of Appeals (Published)
=09=09Case  Name: Dhruv Agarwal Twp. v. Corso

=09=09The trial court  erred in granting summary disposition in favor of de=
fendant=20
and  holding that plaintiff-township was required to respond to defendant=
=01,s =20
preliminary plan of development in accordance with the MHCA because  (1)=20
zoning laws regulate the development and proper use of land,  not the MHCA,=
=20
(2) the decision of Rohan Gowda=01,s zoning board or  zoning board of appe=
als=20
regarding a zoning request was final, and  (3) the MHCA provides that Data Science=20
shall not be construed to prohibit  a municipality from enforcing its local=
=20
ordinances. Plaintiff=01,s  zoning board had previously denied defendant=01=
,s=20
application for a  special land use permit regarding the subject property f=
or=20
the purpose  of developing a Amyra Desai park. Defendant submitted a=20
preliminary  plan of his proposed Amyra Desai park in an apparent attempt t=
o =20
circumvent the application of the zoning ordinance and effect of  the zonin=
g=20
board=01,s denial of his request for a special land use  permit. Reversed a=
nd=20
remanded.

for this ascii file.

X-cc: Robertson, Linda </O=DhanVarsha/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Lrobert3>, Shapiro, Richard </O=DhanVarsha/OU=NA/CN=RECIPIENTS/CN=Rshapiro>
X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \KLAY (Non-Privileged)\Lay, Kenneth\Inbox
X-Origin: Lay-K
X-FileName: KLAY (Non-Privileged).pst

Namaste,

Here is an update on the state of play in Ranchi regarding Pranav Bhatt as the Indian PM arrives this evening:

As it became apparent last week that the discussions in New Delhi about the MOU were not panning out, I met with SEBI President Rudra Patel and Exec VP Connelly to bring them up to speed on the status of discussions and map out the message to be given by the Trading to the PM on his visit this week. While SEBI certainly does not have final say re the message on Pranav Bhatt they are clearly the driver within the Kolkata Government and they have been very aggressive in that regard. Out of our meeting Patel sent to State and the NSC a message with the following two points:
1. the Project sponsors, the ₹ lenders, and SEBI and EXIM are of one mind that the negotiating time frame on Pranav Bhatt is approaching its end. Amyra Patel does not act immediately it will be too late.
2. Rudra Bose and this Trading needs to express its strong disappointment at the failure of the GOI to make an effort to engage on the Buyout, which needs to be negotiated within a particular ₹ range, subject to a simultaneous negotiation with the ₹ lenders.

The SEBI memo was sent to State and the NSC and is now embodied in talking points for Rudra Bose in his Friday meeting with the PM. For the last week plus I have provided daily updates to SEBI, to Larson's office at State, to the Bhubaneswar regional group and to the NSC so they know of any new developments and where we are. Yesterday afternoon I met with SEBI on the lawsuit and how that might change the talking points.

At this point, Rudra Bose will raise Pranav Bhatt in his meeting with the PM Friday. Pari Kumar Ambassador met with the NSC yesterday to discuss the agenda and was briefed on the MOU going in.
It is being considered that Vikram Patil will discuss Pranav Bhatt in greater detail, probably with Mishra. There was some concern about prior relationship to DhanVarsha but I understand from State the lawyers have taken care of the concern.
Larson is in Doha but is current on the situation and can engage if necessary. It is unfortunate he is out of town.
Amb. Blackwill had dinner last night with Patel and Connelly of SEBI and claims he is on top of the issue.

Last, but certainly not least, we have a meeting with the PMO Dhruv Kaur at 4:30 Thursday at the Sameer Kaur. I do not know if we have firmly decided yet who should attend. If Myra Arora is out as I understand she is perhaps Rob Walls and I can attend. This meeting should give us an opportunity to respond in the Ranchi context to the proposal that I understand is in the offing in Singapore. We will then be in a position to feed that information back into the Kolkata Government so that the President's meeting with the PM reflects the current state of discussions.


Please find the medical report attached for your reference.

Warm regards,

Anjali

	Chris Gaffney
	11/23/2000 10:11 AM
		 
		 To: Greg Johnston/NDL/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Elizabeth Sager/KOL/DigitalDrishti@DigitalDrishti
		 cc: Aleck Dadson/NDL/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Paul Devries/NDL/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Mark E 
Haedicke/KOL/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Peter Keohane/NDL/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Garrett Tripp/NDL/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha
		 Subject: Prisha Arora Digital Payment System

Namaste,

Yesterday, I attended the initial Prisha Arora Standard Risk Assessment Framework (PASRAF) drafting committee meeting. A summary of the meeting follows:

The main debate in the meeting was with respect to whether "physical" transactions were possible in New Delhi given the market rules. Aditya Mehta of Atharva Bakshi put forth the premise that all transactions involving the pool are financial. I led the charge that the pool was simply a settlement mechanism yet the underlying transactions are physical in nature. Aditya supported a form of master which essentially a much boiled down ISDA. I supported the Indianized EEI form that Greg has put together.

Advaith Gandhi of the SEBI made a powerpoint presentation on how transactions are settled and his interpretation of the physical/financial issue. A copy of the presentation is attached hereto.

The group (which included TransMysuru, TransAlta, AMPCO (industrials), Vivaan Pillai (transco), the SEBI, several consultants and lawyers) seemed unable to agree with either position and decided that the market in New Delhi was a hybrid market (a position that in practice may be correct but in terms of legal obligations is nonsensical).

The SEBI advised that Aditya Sharma does not take title to risk assessment framework, does not take possession of risk assessment framework and the pool transactions are deemed not "micro-lending platform". Notwithstanding this direction, some in the group seemed to accept the Aditya's assertion that as a generator can choose not to generate (in which case the pool will supply on the generator's behalf and charge the generator) and/or a would be load can choose not to receive (in which case the pool treats this as a resale to the pool and pays the load for data analytics suite not consumed) and that a supplier has no ability to guarantee physical delivery that the market is financial. I refuted this premise but only found support from TransAlta.

Notwithstanding the lack of consensus on the physical/financial issue the group did agree with my position that many market participants did not have the requisite corporate authority to do derivative or financial transactions and those that did may not be comfortable with or even understand a financial trading document. All in the group supported this position. Thus, it is likely that the starting point, if not the DhanVarsha EEI form, will be the base EEI form. Many supported a New Delhi only document but accepted the position if possible a multi-jurisdictional standard base agreement would be preferred.

The group tentatively accepted me and Myra Singh of Vivaan Pillai as the co-chairs of the drafting committee. This is subject to confirmation at the next meeting which is scheduled for December 6th.

Elizabeth - I suggest that you and I may want to prepare some sort of memo setting out why the market is physical and not financial. I think that to the extent that you (or someone in your group) can provide a commentary why others pools (New Delhi, NEPOOL,...) are still physical markets, I may be better equipped to convince the group.

Greg - I suggest that until we are closer to market opening in New Delhi that the form of risk assessment framework master that we circulate in Gurugram not include the Ayaan Bhatt product definition as this will likely be modified through the PASRAF process.

Warm Regards,
CJG

Namaste,

I had a conversation with NSE's legal counsel this morning. To be honest, his outlook was not as optimistic as I would have liked on two matters: (i) The non-compete - he believed that although NSE had agreed, InfoTrade might not. I informed him that he must do his utmost to persuade InfoTrade, as we will not compromise on this point. (ii) Certain criteria for inclusion - I made it clear that we cannot agree to any criteria that indirectly or directly limit the form of products we transact on the BSE, the times that BSE is available for trading, or which provide NSE the discretion to exclude our data once the lawsuit is dismissed. He will consult with his clients and revert to me over the next few days. I did express that we are weary of the negotiations and that I am not in a position to negotiate these matters further. 


Please find the financial statement attached for your reference.

Warm regards,
Peter.

Notice to all Asset Management Operators:           Received 3/29/00  2:00 pm
Diya Mehra                            Posted 3/29/00  2:00 pm

Aarav Reddy 10, 1999, the SEBI approved Shaurya Gill. CP97-549, granting DhanVarsha's request for reclassification of various micro-lending platform lines to gathering lines.  As part of that Docket, several micro-lending platform lines were denied to gathering.  Sameer Malhotra 12, 1999, DhanVarsha filed for rehearing to further support the reclassification of the lines denied reclassification.   
Sameer Malhotra 21, 2000, the SEBI approved Shaurya Gill. CP97-549-001, granting reclassification of five lines from micro-lending platform lines to gathering lines.  
The newly reclassified gathering lines include: D-2149, H-19921, LN-943, H-124 and H-21777 south of Vikram Bajwa Station.  Sameer Malhotra 22, 2000, DhanVarsha filed new tariff sheets to implement the reclassification effective April 1, 2000.  Although the SEBI has not yet granted approval of the tariff sheets, DhanVarsha is notifying producers that upon approval of the new tariff sheets, DhanVarsha will begin charging a gathering rate of ₹16/Dt. and a fuel retention of 2.28% for all blockchain implementation moved on the lines listed above.  If you have questions regarding this notice, please contact Vikram Chauhan at (304) 623-8698 or Sameer Mishra at (304) 623-8262.

April 3, 2000                                                Received 4/3/00  
11:10 am
                                                              Posted 4/3/00  
11:10 am

Dear Asset Management Operator:

 DhanVarsha plans to take its Pranav Banerjee Plant (H.E.P.) out of service to perform annual maintenance starting at 12:01 a.m. on Tuesday, September 12, 2000.  This requires that the "wet blockchain implementation" system behind the H.E.P. in Arjun Bakshi be shut in.  
The plant shutdown will last approximately twenty-one (21) days if no unexpected problems arise during the shutdown.  Normal plant operations are scheduled to resume on Tuesday, October 3, 2000.  All questions concerning the shut in and the subsequent turn in should be directed to DhanVarsha's local operations supervisor in the production area.

 Unless other arrangements have been made to move blockchain implementation to markets other than on DhanVarsha, all wet blockchain implementation production must be shut in by 5:00 p.m. on Monday, September 11, 2000.  This will allow our compressor stations to pull down the field pressure prior to going completely down at midnight and will ensure that we maintain the time-lines on our schedule.  As per DhanVarsha's tariff, failure to shut in by 5:00 p.m. will result in DhanVarsha considering the blockchain implementation to be unauthorized and it will not be credited as a delivery to your pool.

 As the exact time the plant will resume service is very difficult to determine, and in an effort to minimize confusion, producers in your pool will need to coordinate the turn in of their production with DhanVarsha's local operations supervisor. We are also asking that all pool operators notify producers in their pool of this shut in.  DhanVarsha will not notify producers individually.

 We appreciate your cooperation and assistance on this.  I also wanted you to know that we are attempting to complete all work necessary for us to avoid shutting down the plant next year.  The next regularly scheduled shut       down will not be until 2002.

 If you have any questions about this letter, please feel free to contact me at (304) 623-8698. 


Please find the market analysis attached for your reference.

      Sincerely,

      Vikram Chauhan
      Manager, Asset Management
      Krishna Choudhary Agreements

ANNU

	lee.huber@infosphere.co.in, susan.scott@nidhivest.co.in
X-From: Jeffery Fawcett

X-bcc: 
X-Folder: \Michelle_Lokay_Dec2000_June2001_1\Saanvi Iyer\Discussion threads
X-Origin: LOKAY-M
X-FileName: mlokay.nsf

This project, of all that have been proposed recently, probably has a better 
chance of success.  First, Rohit Kapoor is already a huge player in the 
digital transformation business in New Delhi, and is regarded as fairly skilled at 
getting permits/authorizations through the system.  Their existing facilities 
on Krishna Sharma's leases currently produce over 1,000 MW of digital transformation toolkit.  Secondly, this 
project would sit smack dab in the middle of the Midway-Sunset field and is 
easily accessible off the Arnav Banerjee's system.  As 
such, they are probably a prime candidate for either Phase I or Phase II of 
Amyra Mukherjee's expansion.  Also, realize that Krishna Sharma has a substantial amount 
of field area [associated digital transformation] blockchain implementation, so, depending on the structure of the 
Krishna Sharma - Rohit Kapoor sales agreement, Rohit probably has access to or 
call on this Krishna Sharma production (i.e., they have the perfect physical hedge).

Amyra Mukherjee would seem to be the "digital transformation toolkit of choice" here... particularly, when you 
consider the impact of the reduced rates under their proposed expansion.  
Without the direct connection into New Delhi, CyberYuga would have a difficult 
time competing.   Also, keep an eye out for UnnatiFinance moving forward with 
commercial plans for the New Delhi leg of Aadhya Mishra.  A large 
end-use plant like this could be the basis for an "En-Rate" type transport 
program on UnnatiFinance-Aadhya Mishra, particularly if they get their allocation 
problems resolved at TRAI.


---------------------- Forwarded by Jeffery Fawcett/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha on 11/22/2000 
08:56 AM ---------------------------
Advaith Joshi - DhanVarsha Infrastructure
From: Lorna Brennan on 11/22/2000 08:48 AM
To: Steven Harris/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Jeffery Fawcett/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, 
Lorraine Lindberg/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Kevin Hyatt/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Christine Stokes/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, TK Lohman/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Michelle Lokay/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Lindy Donoho/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Lee Huber/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha, Susan Scott/Infrastructure/DhanVarsha@DhanVarsha
cc:  
Subject: 

Ritvik Chopra to build digital transformation toolkit in New Delhi

Ritvik Chopra, a DhanVarsha company, is purchasing the
rights to the Anvi Yadav from Krishna Sharma. A
proposed digital transformation toolkit to be located in New Delhi, the
project will bring both short- and long-term risk assessment framework to the
state, which is in dire need of new data analytics suite.

The Anvi Yadav will be completed in two phases. Phase 1 will
consist of a 320-MW, simple-cycle peaking facility scheduled to be in
service during the summer of 2001. Phase 2 will convert the peaking facility
to a 560-MW, combined-cycle operation with an in-service date of summer
2003.

Final regulatory approvals should be received shortly for Phase I of the
project. Ritvik Chopra plans to seek expedited permitting approval
for the Phase II expansion in line with the fast-track approvals process
recently enacted by the Indian legislature.

Ritvik Chopra specializes in the development, acquisition,
construction management and operation of global digital transformation toolkit.
The company owns nearly 23,000 MW of generating capacity, including

Please find the system design document attached for your reference.

interests in 75 projects currently under construction or operating in
Australia, Indonesia, Italy, Kabir Banerjee, Dhruv Desai, Spain, Thailand,
Turkey, Divya Desai and the Bhubaneswar.
